comments:
The goals of this course are to apply the basic concepts learned in a first year
calculus course to multivariable functions (limits, differentiation, and integration) and to
understand introductory vector calculus.
Students generally felt that this course was a “good continuation of calculus.”
Student ratings of the material covered ranged from “mediocre” to “excellent” and
“challenging.”
Professor Cooper received mixed reviews, but most students generally received
him positively. A few students did not find his lectures useful and felt that he did not
communicate ideas well, while many others found him to be a “great lecturer,” “very
knowledgeable,” and “a very nice person.”
Students believed that the midterms and exams were very difficult, more so than
the other MATH114 sections. Some students also felt that not having to turn in
homework was a detriment to their learning.

This course covers the functions of several variables, vector-valued functions,
partial derivatives and applications, double and triple integrals, conic sections, polar
coordinates, vectors and analytic geometry, and first and second order ordinary
differential equations. It includes applications to physical sciences. Use of symbolic
manipulation and graphics software in calculus is also taught.
Students were generally content with this course, describing it as “decent,” but not
overly stimulating or enjoyable. Students agreed that the concepts learned in this course
were “important” and found the course to be “informative.” One student liked that it tied
in concepts from physics, which allowed students to understand the mathematical
concepts from a different perspective. Recitations included weekly quizzes, which
“reflected the concepts learned in class,” but some students thought this time could have
been more effectively spent reviewing the material.
Overall, students described Professor Pantev as an “average” lecturer, and most
did not find his lectures to be very “useful.” Several students reported relying more on
the textbook than on lectures. Although ”knowledgeable” and “passionate” about the
material, some students found Professor Pantev to be an “ineffective communicator” of
the material. Some thought he moved too quickly, while others appreciated that he wrote
all of his notes on the board and worked through many practice examples. Students
unanimously described him as “nice,” “responsive to emails,” and very willing to answer
questions both in class and in office hours, though one thought his answers were “seldom
very helpful.” Students appreciated that he hosted “interactive and helpful” review
sessions before exams.
This course fulfills the formal reasoning requirement, and Math 104 is a
prerequisite. This class was described as being “doable” but at times overwhelmingly
“fast-paced.” Exams were described as “fair” and not “overly difficult.” One even noted
that the second exam had a “median/mean in the high 80’s” and that questions were
“straightforward.” Students generally agreed that the information was challenging but
could be understood if enough individual effort was put in outside of class. Many
students who took this course had already been exposed to the material, which made the
curve more difficult for those who had not.

The goals of this course are to apply the basic concepts learned in a first year
calculus course to multivariable functions (limits, differentiation, and integration) and to
understand introductory vector calculus.
MATH114 was described as a “good calculus course” with “interesting” material.
Some students found the course to be quite difficult and the lectures a little “dry,” but
overall the course itself was given average to good reviews.
Professor Powers was considered a “knowledgeable” and “nice” man by most of
the students. However, many also felt that he had a lot of difficulty communicating
material to the class. Many students were frustrated by the amount of mistakes the
professor made and his deviations from the textbook.
Students felt that this course relied mainly on “self-study” and that the textbook
was useless due to its poor teaching style.
